div.p:
Dr Norton Shaw
will I suppose be
a better hand for
looking over the
sheets than Mr Galton and he
volunteered his
aid most frankly
when I asked him
about Galton's
qualifications.
He edits the journal
of the R.G.S. I should
like to get back the
corrections I sent
to the other man
if the slips are
not destroyed which
contained them.

I would like a
couple of wood cuts
to shew the form
of the fashion of
dressing the hair
in London, one is
an imitation of
the glory round
the virgin's head.
If it can be done
I shall send you
a little drawing.

I shall bring
up two pieces of
manuscript tomorrow
got your note
yesterday. If you
are not as
much vexed with
me as I was with
the revises I'm
mistaken. Yyou seem
as if about to say
"a plague upon the
fellow what does
he mean". I don't
wonder at your
getting crusty with
me, but I can't
muster a single grumble
at you in return.

I have answered the enclosed. It need
not be preserved after you have read it
